newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss stocks end firm on Wall-Street led gains.
newsitem.headline: Swiss stocks end firm on Wall-Street led gains.

text.p: Swiss shares ended Monday higher, boosted by late European buying after Wall Street shares staged gains in early U.S. trade.
The firm dollar supported dollar-sensitive stocks.
Traders were waiting to see how U.S. economic data due later in the week will affect stocks.
The blue-chip Swiss Market Index (SMI) ended up 41.0 points, or 0.7 percent, at the day's high of 5,888.0.
The broad Swiss Performance Index was up 24.74 points at 3,737.25.
Dealers said activity was slow compared with recent sessions. Bourse volume was a modest 1.90 billion Swiss francs.
Most-traded Novartis recovered from early weakness to end flat at 2,379.
Nestle, which has lately been lagging behind the market, climbed 33 francs to 1,932. One dealer said the stock profited from a recommendation.
SBC fell 10.50 francs to 414.50 after it lowered the nominal value of its shares to 40 francs from 50 as part of an already-announced capital reduction.
UBS rose two francs to 1,691, while CS Group was unchanged at 204.25.

Specialty chemical firms Ciba and Clariant continued to rise. Clariant shot up 45 francs to 1,145. The stock has seen a solid rise since the company announced better-than-expected half-year sales last week.
ABB, Alusuisse, Sulzer, Swissair were among the gainers on the day.
Among insurers, Zurich and Swiss Re saw bigger advances.
